data.title: Introduction
data.meta_description: This book approaches the extremely varied work of Rose Tremain through two unifying principles: the significance of space and the rewriting of realism. Although Tremain has been labelled as a historical writer, the critical examination of her novels uncovers the more...
data.text:

Tremain, Rose. 1999b. Tremain’s Terrain. History Today 49 (10): 62.

Tremain, Rose. 2006a. Moth. In The Darkness of Wallis Simpson, 165–178. London: Vintage. (Original work published 2005).

Tremain, Rose. 2006b. The Cherry Orchard, with Rugs. In The Darkness of Wallis Simpson, 179–188. London: Vintage. (Original work published 2005).

Tremain, Rose. 2006c. The Ebony Hand. In The Darkness of Wallis Simpson, 125–146. London: Vintage. (Original work published 2005).

Tremain, Rose. 2016. Realms of Gold: Rose Tremain on Forty Years of Writing. The Royal Society of Literature. http://rsliterature.org/library-article/realms-of-gold-rose-tremain-on-forty-years-of-writing/. Accessed 16 January 2017.

Turner, Nick. 2010. Post-War British Women Novelists and the Canon. London: Continuum.

Turner, Nick. 2013. Realism, Women Writers and the Contemporary British Novel. In Realisms in Contemporary Culture: Theories, Politics and Medial Configurations, ed. Dorothee Birke and Stella Butter, 49–69. Boston: Walter de Gruyter.

Westphal, Bertrand. 2011. Geocriticism. Real and Fictional Spaces, trans. Robert T. Tally Jr,. New York: Palgrave Macmillan.
